case_vignette:
A 42-year-old man presents with a four-day history of experiencing headache, malaise, and stabbing right-sided headache. Two days after his initial symptoms appeared, he developed a rash over the area of pain. He reports that he went hiking through the Texas hill country prior to becoming ill. The patient is otherwise in good health and has an unremarkable medical history. Physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. In addition, he has no relevant social or family history. The patient is a 42-year-old male who is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. The patient has no relevant social or family history. The patient is a 42-year-old who is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. Two days after the onset of symptoms, he developed a rash over the area of pain. The patient's physical examination reveals unilateral erythematous, thin, raised plaques over the right forehead. The patient has no relevant social or family history.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing headache, malaise, and a stabbing right-sided headache for the past four days. Two days after these symptoms started, I developed a rash over the area of pain.
Can you describe the appearance of the rash?
The rash consists of red, thin, raised plaques located on my right forehead.
Have you had chickenpox in the past?
I don't have any information on whether I've had chickenpox in the past.
Do you have any other symptoms like fever, chills, or changes in vision?
No, I don't have any other symptoms like fever, chills, or changes in vision.
Does the rash have any blisters or is it just flat plaques?
The rash consists of thin, raised plaques; I did not mention any blisters.
Final Diagnosis: Herpes Zoster (Shingles)
